Housing Affordability Crisis Deepening as Prices Soar 60% Since 2019, Harvard Report Warns
Jamela Adam
October 5, 2025 4 min read
In this article:
MSFT

Homeownership rates fell in 2024 for the first time in eight years as soaring home prices made ownership unattainable for many, Harvard University's Joint Center for Housing Studies found. As of early 2025, prices are up 60% nationwide since 2019 and still rising at a rate of 3.9% year over year, according to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller US National Home Price Index. Consequently, the U.S. median existing single-family home price hit a new high of $429,400 in 2025, according to the National Association of Realtors.
High prices aren't the only problem. The rise in mortgage rates since 2020 has also increased the income required to afford a typical home. In January 2020, the average 30-year fixed mortgage was around 3.72%, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Today, it's around 6.30%. How to make homeownership possible
Homeownership has become less affordable, but that doesn't mean it's impossible. Here are a few ways to lower your homeownership costs and make your dream of becoming a homeowner a reality. Look Into Home-Buying Assistance Programs Many federal, state and city programs often help with down payments, closing costs or lower interest rates for those who qualify. For example, FHA loans only require 3.5% down if you have at least a 580 credit score, and VA and USDA loans require no down payment as long as you meet the eligibility requirements.

You can always move up later as your income grows. Expand Your Search Radius If you're flexible with where you want to live, consider expanding your search radius since prices can differ pretty dramatically just a few miles away. Look at up-and-coming neighborhoods, nearby suburbs or small towns within commuting distance. Housing in these areas is generally more affordable compared to the city center.

Shop Around for a Mortgage Don't take the first offer. Get pre-approved with at least three lenders so you can compare rates and terms. Even a slightly lower rate or lower fees can save you thousands of dollars over the life of your loan. House Hack to Offset Costs If you don't mind having housemates, consider buying a duplex, triplex or single-family home with multiple rooms. This way, you can live in one unit and rent out the others to cover part of your mortgage and help you qualify for a bigger loan.
